Award.AwardTitle: MARGINS: Collaborative Research: Illuminating the Architecture of the Greater Mount St. Helens Magmatic System from Slab to Surface
Award.AbstractNarration:
To better understand volcanic activity, it is fundamental to get an accurate representation of magma generation zones and storage regions in the Earth?s crust and upper mantle. Illuminating the architecture of the plumbing system beneath volcanoes will allow scientists to determine (1) at which depths and conditions magmas are generated, and (2) the shapes and sizes of pathways and reservoirs along which magma travels towards the surface. Such knowledge will allow scientists to make more informed predictions on the durations of volcanic crises and on the total volume of erupted material during eruptive episodes.

This project focuses on the Mount St. Helens volcanic edifice, (WA, USA), whose explosive eruption in 1980 attracted world?s attention, and was the first volcano to be thoroughly monitored with modern instruments. Mount St. Helens provides an ideal setting to apply state-of-the-art geophysical and geochemical techniques to image its subterranean roots: It is active, easily accessible, and has a well recorded past history. The project will use several different methods (active and passive source seismic tomography and scattered wave imaging, magnetotelluric imaging, petrology and geochemistry), involving a large collaborative team, to image the volcano?s plumbing system with unprecedented resolution from the subducting plate to the surface. The results will be informative for many other volcanoes around the world, particularly those located along the infamous Pacific Ring of Fire.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project fundamentally altered our views of the nature of magmatism in the southern Washington Cascades volcanic arc, and of the role played by plutons/batholiths (large igneous rock intrusions) in the distribution of magma in the crust, and the origin and meaning of the Southern Washington Cascades Conductor anomaly. This result stands to change how we consider the relationship between structural controls and magmatism throughout the western part of North America.

We  identified the  source and migration paths of melt from below the crust into the near surface, the association between the Saint Helens Seismic Zone and the West Rainier Seismic Zone that are both associated with concentrations of small earthquakes and a thin band of metasediments identified by magnetotelluric (MT) imaging was made, indicating that the lower strength of the metasediments compared to surrounding rock formations focusses seismicity in this thin band. This project also lead to the first identification of the Spirit Lake Batholith tsince it was revealed as a large electrically resistive crustal block hrough the MT image.

Rather than the large crustal-scale conductivity anomaly previously imaged by much lower resolution long-period magnetotelluric efforts of the past with their sparse arrays of stations, by using a very dense wideband MT array specifically designed for 3-D imaging at high resolution we resolved that the SWCC is in fact a very narrow band of highly conductive metasediments surrounding the highly resistive batholith and then extending up along the Saint Helens and West Rainier Seismic Zones.

 We also were able to determine that physical continuity of the zone of high conductivity beneath Mount Saint Helens with an upwelling conductive zone beneath Mount Adams, as was suggested by Hill's 2-D inversion of a single MT profile from MSH to Mt Adams was not a required feature of the data when the full MT data set was inverted in 3-D. Indeed the magmatic source for Mt Adams likely lies in the deep crust and may be associated instead with the sub-batholitic zone of partial melt.

The batholith is relatively impermeable compared with the metasedimentary band surrounding it, and melt from below is therefore channeled around the periphery of the batholith and up into the metasedimentary band where it erupts in localized zones that serve as the primary magma source for Mount Saint Helens and Mount Adams, both of which lie off of the main axis of the Cascade Volcanic Arc. 

 

Broader Impacts


This project supported a number of undergraduates who gained research experience through geophysical (magnetotelluric - i.e. electromagnetic methods) field work in Yellowstone National Park, some of whom also analysed some of that data and made presentations at the American Geophysical Union annual meeting. The project also supported PhD students and postdoctoral researchers who were engaged both in fieldwork and also in development of new/improved methods in geophysical data analysis and interpretation. This project contributed materially to the successful completion of a PhD degree by an Oregon State University graduate student.

A valuable magnetotelluric data set was archived and made available in the public domain for free and open use by other researchers.

The project provided the first look at a previously undetected batholith,providing evidence for its origin and its influence on melt migration from a source zone we have detected beneath it in the lower crust and below. This will have a significant impact on volcanology in general, as other examples of the mediating influence of variations in mid-to-upper crustal permeability as a control on melt migration, regional seismicity and the origin of volcanic centers are sought.

We have also identified the existence of a very thin band of highly conductive material in the upper to mid crust that we have attributed to metasediments originally emplaced as marine sediments during crustal accretion (that is, the process by which new blocks of crustal material wwereas added to the continent from the subducting plates to the west) along the continental margin. This band coincides with two major seismic zones, suggesting mechanical weakness. If similar high-resolution wideband MT surveys are conducted in similar terranes in future, a better understanding of the genesis of regional seismicity may be uncovered.

We have also demonstrated that Oregon State University's recently developed "subaerial" magnetotelluric deployment method, involving no ground disturbance, can be used to establish magnetotelluric monitoring sites in areas of volcanic risk, where otherwise permitting restrictions would have prohibited establishment of MT monitoring equipment.

We have gained a greater understanding of crustal scale magmatic processes in an area of great social and economic importance in the Pacific Northwest. This provides new insights into the processes that govern long-term volcanic risk. Our ongoing work at Mount Saint Helens may provide additional innsights that could lead to new monitoring methods for the eruption/recharge cycle at active volcanoes.
